awd_titl_txt: III-CXT: Collaborative Research: Integrated Modeling of Biological Nanomachines
awd_abstract_narration: Biological nanomachines are the assemblies that carry out all the basic biological processes in a living organism. Electron cryo-microscopy (cryoEM) is the most appropriate structural tool to determine molecular structures of biological nanomachines that generally consist of multiple protein subunits and/or nucleic acids with a total mass greater than 0.5 million Daltons.  The goal is to develop information discovery and integration methodologies for deriving atomic models of nanomachines. Such models will be derived from 3-dimensional (3-D) cryoEM mass density function (i.e. a volumetric density map) in conjunction with physics of protein folding and informatics data. This project is made possible by an integration of the expertise of five investigators in computer graphics, computational biophysics, structural informatics and cryoEM. The intellectual merit of this research is highlighted by the computational approaches of extracting structural information from low-resolution, complex cryoEM volume densities and integrating this information into classical protein structure modeling paradigms, such as comparative modeling and ab initio modeling, for understanding biological nanomachines.  The three research goals involve information discovery, information integration and validation of the proposed algorithms.  The proposed research will have significant impacts in three disparate disciplines: computer science, molecular modeling, and cryoEM.  Furthermore, the team will disseminate their resulting tools freely to the academic community and will host a workshop towards the end of the project. To enhance the impact of their research, the investigators will integrate research with education at each member institution with an eye towards diversity. In particular, these investigators will develop a virtual didactic course in modeling of biological nanomachines for graduate and senior undergraduate students at the five participating institutions.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to provide an integrated computational approach for building structural models of macromolecular complexes based on a 3-D density function generated by cryoEM (cryo-electron microscopy) imaging. The intellectual merit of the proposed research resides in the development of novel methods for extracting useful and reliable information from raw cryoEM volumes and for integrating such information as constraints into existing and new modeling paradigms. 

The Washington University site was responsible for developing geometric techniques for feature extraction from 3D volumes, and for guiding the making of structural models by these features. To this end, we have made significant progress in three directions. First, we developed and refined algorithms for extracting a density skeleton from the volume. The skeleton robustly captures tubular and plate-like density distributions in the cryoEM volume, which correspond very well to alpha-helices (tubular), loops (tubular) and beta-sheets (plate-like). The skeleton has been playing a critical role in our automated method (SSEhunter) for detecting secondary structure elements in a cryoEM volume. Second, using the topology of the density skeleton and helix prediction in the primary sequence, we developed a graph-matching-based algorithm that identifies connectivity among helices detected in the cryoEM volume. The connectivity allows an initial backbone of the protein to be constructed, making the first step in de novo modeling of the protein structure. Third, we developed a fast algorithm for flexibly fitting atomic structures of a template model into the cryoEM volume, guided by the locations of helices on the template model and those detected in the cryoEM volume. Using geometric registration techniques, the fitting adapts well to large, hinge-like motions, and gives a good initial placement of the atomic structure that can be fed to a model refinement program. 

In collaboration with the Baylor College of Medicine site, we have developed a software package specifically for structure creation from cryoEM density volumes, known as Gorgon. This visual, interactive software hosts a suite of computational algorithms as well as interactive functions, and is freely distributed (with sample data, documentation, and video guides) online at http://gorgon.wustl.edu.


Last Modified: 10/29/2010
Modified by: Tao Ju
